awd_titl_txt: M-theory, Superspace and Higher Spin Theories
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds the research activities of Professors Katrin Becker, Melanie Becker, and Ergin Sezgin at Texas A&M University.

String theory provides a framework for describing gravity in a way which is consistent with the laws of quantum mechanics. However, string theories generally require that there exist extra dimensions beyond those of width, length, and height.   Such extra dimensions must be rolled into very small spaces, and the shapes of these spaces determine which elementary particles are predicted by string theory.  For these reasons, it is important to understand the detailed shapes of these extra dimensions.  Likewise, combining Einstein's theory of gravity with quantum mechanics involves a hypothetical particle --- the so-called "graviton"  --- which transmits gravitational interactions and carries two units of spin.  However, string theory can also give rise to remarkable extensions of Einstein's theory which involve higher-spin analogues of the graviton.   For these reasons, string theory can have profound consequences for early-universe physics.  In their research, Professors Becker, Becker, and Sezgin aim to investigate these and other fundamental questions involving the connections between string theory, gravity, and higher-spin theories.  As such, this project advances the national interest by promoting progress in fundamental science within the United States.  This project is also envisioned to have significant broader impacts.  Not only will this research further develop the interface between string theory and mathematics, but it will also provide an arena for the critical training for postdocs and students.  Professors Becker, Becker, and Sezgin will also give public lectures on their research results and organize scientific workshops to help advance the field.

More technically, Professors Becker, Becker, and Sezgin aim to construct the full spacetime effective action of different string theory and M-theory compactifications to all orders in the slope parameter and its formulation in superspace.  Their goal is to use physical ideas and methods to solve long-standing problems in mathematics.  Further, Professors Becker, Becker, and Sezgin will study the holographic description of higher-spin theory, its coupling to matter, spontaneous symmetry breaking, cosmological solutions and their consequences for early-universe physics.   They will also study specific aspects of a geometrical description of duality symmetries of strings and branes within a framework known as exceptional field theory.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award was used to support three principal investigators and their group of postdoctoral fellows, graduate students and visitors. Their research projects deal with fundamental aspects of string theory and M-theory and their implications for particle physics and mathematics.

K. Becker and M. Becker: Our efforts have been focused on further developing our work dealing with rewriting eleven-dimensional supergravity in four-dimensional N=1 superspace. Eleven-dimensional supergravity is the low-energy limit of M-theory, a theory that many believe is our most promising candidate to be a theory of quantum gravity. It is then desirable to find a formulation of eleven-dimensional supergravity with manifest symmetries (we focus on N=1 supersymmetry in four dimensions). Such a formulation might hold clues on how the theory behaves beyond the supergravity approximation (where it becomes a theory of quantum gravity). Such a formulation is also user friendly when it comes to application to particle physics or condensed matter physics.

In one publication we considered the toy model of five-dimensional supergravity constructed in four-dimensional superspace. It is a toy model since it deals with five-dimensional supergravity as opposed to eleven-dimensional supergravity. The toy model captures many of the interesting properties of eleven-dimensional supergravity, which is the main case of interest, yet it happens to be much simpler. We have, for example, been able to construct the superspace version of higher derivative corrections to five-dimensional supergravity in four-dimensional superspace. Repeating such a calculation for the eleven-dimensional case is a goal for future projects. Then we also introduce a general covariant framework relevant for describing any higher dimensional supergravity theory in external four-dimensional superspace with $n$ additional internal coordinates. The case of main interest is eleven-dimensional supergravity. And even tough we made much progress at the linear level (like working out the component structure of a theory in eleven dimensions with 4 supersymmetries closing off-shell) we hope to be able to use the framework we introduced to obtain the full non-linear theory.The projects worked out are envisioned to have broader impact since a framework has been developed to find a formulation of M-theory with some manifest supersymmetry. Many believe M-theory is our best candidate to be a theory of quantum gravity. Moreover, the projects involved graduate students and postdoctoral fellows, and thus provide critical training to junior physicists working in this field.

E. Sezgin: Higher spin theories, higher derivative extensions of supergravity theories and duality symmetries are highly relevant in the development of a consistent theory of quantum gravity.  Our projects have made contributions to these fields.

 Higher spin theories constitute a remarkable extension of Einstein's theory of gravity to incorporate an infinite tower of higher and higher spin fields such that there is a much larger symmetry principle than that of Einstein's gravity. Such an extension is motivated by the ultra-high energy limit of string theory which is the most promising candidate for a successful description of quantum gravity. Ultimately, we would like to understand their consequences for the very early universe physics.  Our main effort so far has primarily been on re-formulation of these theories in a way that improves our ability in understanding their symmetries and explore their solutions. We have put forward a geometric formulation based on a novel type of gauge theory, which we call Frobenius-Chern-Simons gauge theory, formulated on extended spacetime which includes four extra coordinates that are non-commutative. Our studies so far in this direction may have implications in mathematics as well.

 Another area in which we have made contributions is the duality symmetries in supergravity theories, governed by supersymmetry principle alone, or as low energy limits of string theory in diverse backgrounds. Duality transformations relate theories that describe seemingly different physical situations, but in fact all emerging from one underlying theory. We have contributed to the description of duality symmetries of supergravity theory in eleven dimensions which is believed to be the low energy limit of M theory, related to string theories via various limits and dualities. This work may have implications in mathematics as well. Furthermore, we investigated the highly nontrivial problem of whether the duality symmetries survive higher derivative extensions of supergravities. Such extensions have crucial consequences for describing quantum gravity at higher and higher energies, with implications for early universe physics. A graduate student has been trained in carrying out successful work in these projects.
